moves.1. g3: I'm not really comfortable with these flank openings as I do not know the best way to counter them. I dislike to become overextended so I don't usually throw my pawns forward.
moves.1... d5 2. Bg2 Nf6 3. Nf3 c5 4. Nc3 e6 5: ?! This allows me to forward my centre pawns one rank and liberate my light-squared bishop. It also makes his fianchettoed bishop bad. I can say that the bishop on g2 won't play any role whatsoever in this game. Unfortunately, my opponent didn't need it!
moves.8... d4 9. Ne2: 9. e5? loses a pawn after 9... dxc3 10. exf6 Bxf6.
moves.9... e5 10. Nh4 Nh5: ?! A discovered attack on the knight on h4 and at the same time controlling f4, but my own knight will be vulnerable to discovered attack later on.
moves.11... Be6: I didn't mind the trade of a knight for my dark-squared bishop as it's blocked by my own pawns.
moves.13... Nxd4 14. c3: Better than the alternative 14. Qxh5 Nxc2 15. Rb1 Nb4.
moves.14... Nf6 15. cxd4 cxd4: At this point I was satisfied with how the opening went. My knight has obviously a brighter future ahead of him than my opponent's light-squared bishop.
moves.16. a4 a5: ? Loses the exchange, but perhaps his bishop is worth more in this position than the rook?
moves.17. Ba3 Qc7 18. Bxf8 Kxf8: Wrong capture! My opponent can now quickly intensify the pressure on f7.
moves.19. f4: This move does create a nice outpost for my knight on e3. Certainly when there is the option of winning the exchange back!
moves.19... Qb6 20. Rb1 Ng4 21. f5 Ne3 22. Qh5: Unfortunately, I can not capture the rook as 23. fxe6 creates a mate threat on f7 and I therefore have no time to retreat the knight. Also, I figured 22... Bxb3 leaves my rook on a8 in peril as 23. Qxh7 Nxf1 24. Qh8+ Ke7 25. Qxa8 Ne3 favoures White. All of this could have been avoided if I had played 18... Rxf8 instead.
moves.22... Bc8 23. Rfc1: ?! It would be better to keep the rook on the f-file as 23... h6 would have allowed 24. f6.
moves.23... h6 24. g4 f6: Trying to keep a strong dark-squared pawn-chain.
moves.27. Qg6+ Kg8 28. h4 Qd8: Stopping 29. g5 but allowing White to double rooks on the c-file.
moves.29. Rc5 Qb6 30. Rbc1: This allows me to capture two pawns, but all of my pieces will be pinned to their spots.
moves.30... Qxb3 31. Rc5c7 Qxa4: My position is rather hopeless. I can only hope my opponent makes a mistake. My combination of queen and knight is unable to create serious threats for my opponents king.
moves.32. g5 hxg5 33. hxg5 fxg5 34. Qxg5 Rf8 3: No other way to protect my bishop. The bishop can't move because of Qg7#, but this move allows the nice shot...
moves.36. Rc7c8+: I gave up, as 36... Bxc8 37. Rxc8+ is mate after 37... Kh7 38. Qh5# Well done, mustafaupk.
